content:
Hi Aidan.

Blocking is not possible in Thunderbird. You may be able to do it at the server.

What you can do is Thunderbird, as you seem to know, is filter messages to trash, junk, or somewhere else. To start creating a message filter, use Tools (menu) > Message Filters.

You can access the same function through the three horizontal lines on the toolbar.
creator: mozilla98

content:
Select a message, then Message/Create Filter From Message... Press Alt if the Menu Bar with Message is hidden.

But it's better to block (or whitelist) senders through the options offered in the webmail settings for the account - which are applied even when TB is closed or before mail is downloaded.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Možná příčina je v tom, že Thunderbird je spuštěný jako správce (admin). Podle několika uživatelů přetahování (drag & drop) příloh nefunguje, jestliže Thunderbird běží „jako administrátor“.

Zkus: klikni pravým tlačítkem na zástupce Thunderbird → Vlastnosti → Kompatibilita → odškrtnout „Spustit jako administrátor“. Poté znovu spusť Thunderbird a vyzkoušej táhnout soubor.
creator: Ansamb

content:
1: Yes.

2: No, you will use the same accounts as before, as you mentioned in #1.

3. Depends on what you mean by “empower” and “control” and what you want to accomplish. People who know Thunderbird can set up gmail and iCloud accounts in a few minutes. Thunderbird can do very much. Some complexity comes with power. There are several very knowledgeable people on this forum who can help you with specific issues. For example, iCloud requires an app-specific password that you must create at Apple. gmail may also. I do not know. Other people here know gmail and Thunderbird well.
creator: mozilla98

content:
Try this:

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformation on windows pc
  2. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  3. exit thunderbird - IMPORTANT
  4. you are now in the profile folder. copy ALL of it and save to external media
  5. install thunderbird on linux, if not already done
  6. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  7. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  8. exit thunderbird
  9. you are in the profile. Paste what you copied here ########
  10. restart thunderbird

CAVEAT: from various linux posts, i think the profile is not consistent to thunderbird default, so you may need to check that.
creator: davidsk

content: Message filter is a text file in each account. name is msgfilterrules.dat. Exit thunderbird and open in a text editor, such as notepad. I would first make a backup copy. You may be able to manually edit there, save, restart thunderbird and see how it works.

content: the problem is not with the sender. I get a kick back on many messages. The problem is with the Firefox account with error in SPF and DKIM. Help me correct them, please.
creator: gloriakahn

content:
The message that you shared does not provide evidence of that kind of problem. Would you please post screenshots of error messages that mention SPF and DKIM issues?

What do you mean by a "Firefox account"? Do you mean your popbox account? Firefox is not relevant here, and there is no Thunderbird account.

SPF and DKIM authenticate the sender, so problems with them do indeed indicate a problem with the sender. Would you please post a screenshot of your SMTP settings? You can find them in Account settings > click on account name > "edit outgoing server..."
creator: mozilla98

content:
Can I assume you have rebooted? That can often fix such anomalies. Otherwise...

I'll guess that it's your anti-virus that's interfering with file writing. As a test, try temporarily disabling your AV (MS Defender?) to see if that helps. Be careful, though - it may have flagged a questionable email, triggering the "write" error.
creator: rednoise
